node.title: 'Penis worms' took up residence in shells long before hermit crabs
node.alt: Artist impression penis worm in hyolith shell
node.description: Millions of years before crabs did it, lowly penis worms were already living the hermit lifestyle,  fossils found in China suggest.
node.content:
["Crabs do it, octopuses too, but now it seems lowly creatures called \"penis worms\"\u00a0may have been the first to \"hermit\"\u00a0themselves away in shells.", "These marine creatures, endearingly nicknamed for their characteristic shape \u2014\u00a0and officially called priapulids \u2014\u00a0are not known today to hide in the shells of others, but scientists have now found evidence they once did.", "A fossil deposit in southern China has yielded four examples of 500-million-year-old Cambrian penis worms, called Eximipriapulus,\u00a0squeezed inside conical shells of another long-extinct fossil group, called hyoliths.", "The findings are published in the journal Current Biology.", "\"The worms are always sitting snugly within these same types of shells, in the same position and orientation\", said study co-author Dr Martin Smith from Durham University in a statement.", "\"A 'hermiting' lifestyle has never been documented or observed in living or fossil penis worms.\"", "Indeed, he said, the earliest direct observation of hermiting\u00a0dates back to the age of the dinosaurs, hundred of millions of years after the Cambrian.", "", "
The penis worm partially inside its hyolith shell home.(Professor Zhang Xiguang/Yunnan University)
", "Laetitia Gunton, a marine worm expert from the Australian Museum, said the soft-bodied worms would have adapted to needing protection at a time when there was an explosion of lifeforms \u2014\u00a0including predators.", "\"Worms by their nature are a nice easy thing to eat because they're squishy and nutritious so they've had to come up with good defensive strategies,\" said Dr Gunton, who was not involved in the study.", "These days penis worms live in marine sediments, but plenty of other animals have adapted to the hermit lifestyle, including of course the\u00a0hermit crab, which hides in abandoned shells.", "\"Some octopuses also hide in shells,\" Dr Gunton said.", "And some animals\u00a0don't always wait until the owner of the shell has abandoned it.", "\"The worms that I work on, the annelids, can bore into live mussel and oyster shells and live inside there,\" Dr Gunton said.", "\"Other worms make their own tube out of sticking bits of shell together.\"", "The penis worm fossils were found in the Guanshan fossil deposits in eastern Yunnan Province, which are famous for their\u00a0preservation of soft tissues.", "\"It's quite difficult to investigate these sort of worms because they're all squishy and you just don't get fossil records of them,\" Dr Gunton said.", "\"So this is quite cool that they've got these.\""]
